content.body:
> <@littledan:matrix.org> OK, coming in at a bit under 100 hours from when I promised this, here's the edits I'd make to the slides:
> - Don't you want to use the run() function in your wrap() implementation? (Aside: rename run())
> - I think mixing in the part about monkey-patching console.log is a distraction which would be better removed.
> - I would replace the React Cache example with OpenTelemetry (legendecas can do this as he knows that area much better than me). Really, the OpenTelemetry case of holding a span ID instead of an initial timestamp has exactly the same needs--we should say this explicitly.
> - Slide 18 is really key (maybe reference the main thread scheduling proposal? maybe not?) but the code doesn't then correspond to anything about prioritization, so it's a little confusing
> - In general, let's say "async context" intead of "async stack" to reinforce the intuition around the terms. Also "stack" implies linear memory usage for the number of async items, which is definitely not the case here, but definitely is the case with general async stack traces (which is a specific non-goal here, and which we should probably avoid comparing this with in slide 19, as it will probably make browsers uncomfortable)
> - All the stuff about "the dynamic scoping elephant" should be probably rephrased as "Bonus slides (if time allows): ocap analysis" and then just defer to Mark to say he thought about it and decided it's OK. I expect the committee to continue disagreeing internally on whether this deserves to be called "dynamic scoping", and really, that's all irrelevant

(and, please let me know if you won't do these edits and I should make them)
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @littledan:matrix.org

OK, coming in at a bit under 100 hours from when I promised this, here's the edits I'd make to the slides:

  • Don't you want to use the run() function in your wrap() implementation? (Aside: rename run())
  • I think mixing in the part about monkey-patching console.log is a distraction which would be better removed.
  • I would replace the React Cache example with OpenTelemetry (legendecas can do this as he knows that area much better than me). Really, the OpenTelemetry case of holding a span ID instead of an initial timestamp has exactly the same needs--we should say this explicitly.
  • Slide 18 is really key (maybe reference the main thread scheduling proposal? maybe not?) but the code doesn't then correspond to anything about prioritization, so it's a little confusing
  • In general, let's say "async context" intead of "async stack" to reinforce the intuition around the terms. Also "stack" implies linear memory usage for the number of async items, which is definitely not the case here, but definitely is the case with general async stack traces (which is a specific non-goal here, and which we should probably avoid comparing this with in slide 19, as it will probably make browsers uncomfortable)
  • All the stuff about "the dynamic scoping elephant" should be probably rephrased as "Bonus slides (if time allows): ocap analysis" and then just defer to Mark to say he thought about it and decided it's OK. I expect the committee to continue disagreeing internally on whether this deserves to be called "dynamic scoping", and really, that's all irrelevant
(and, please let me know if you won't do these edits and I should make them)

content.body: Or do you mean specific to timers?
I mean that plus this plumbing through all the web APIs (not specific to timers)
So like the node extension you made but it restores across web APIs including timers in exactly the way yoavâ€™s work does

Currently we (workerd) has to capture the context manually for timers and queueMicrotask web apis. These are still fundamentally based on the v8 API tho. Basically when a timer is set we call GetContinuationPreservedEmbedderData to get the current storage context and enter that manually when the callback function is called. Pretty simple
queueMicrotask will be handled for us once v8 fixes the current limitations
Do you maintain patches onto V8 for workerd?
Oh, we also capture manually for wrapped functions and AsyncResource

> <@jasnell:matrix.org> queueMicrotask will be handled for us once v8 fixes the current limitations

Which limitation?
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @jasnell:matrix.org
queueMicrotask will be handled for us once v8 fixes the current limitations
Which limitation?

content.body: We do but none for this yet
The limitation that v8 is not attaching the context to EnqueueMicrotask

We certainly could float a patch that covers the queueMicrotask issue but we'd rather that just be addressed upstream. For now we're fine with it not working for thenables but would like that not to be permanent

The thenable bug is solved by copying https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:v8/src/builtins/builtins-microtask-queue-gen.cc;l=238-247;drc=bf9ffddf05af0586dc82cd2a320508cd5dcfbc3c into https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:v8/src/builtins/builtins-microtask-queue-gen.cc;l=191-221;drc=bf9ffddf05af0586dc82cd2a320508cd5dcfbc3c
The generic microtask bug is in that same function, but it's more complicated
Oh nice. Since we have a workaround for queueMicrotask we might be able to just float the change for thenables then wait for the rest
I'm assuming you're not using any Blink code for your timers?
Correct

content.formatted_body: I recently scraped together this Docker image with a custom build of Deno that supports the AsyncContext proposal in native async/await code: https://github.com/benjamn/deno/pull/2

content.body:
```
docker run -it --rm benjamn/deno:async-thenables repl
```
should give you a Deno REPL where you can play with `AsyncContext`, provided you have Docker installed
content.formatted_body:
docker run -it --rm benjamn/deno:async-thenables repl

should give you a Deno REPL where you can play with AsyncContext, provided you have Docker installed

content.body: I don't plan to support this Deno fork in the long run, but I thought it might be useful to share, so others can check their intuitions, suggest test cases, identify context loss pitfalls, etc
(that Docker image is "only" 162MB, thanks mostly to Deno being a single standalone 90MB binary)

If you're not against it, I would just implement `AsyncLocalStorage` and provide maybe a JS wrapper around it to conform to the current `AsyncContext` API
content.formatted_body: If you're not against it, I would just implement AsyncLocalStorage and provide maybe a JS wrapper around it to conform to the current AsyncContext API

(if any)

we've got customers currently asking specifically for node.js compat with ALS so we're pretty much committed to supporting both apis

content.body: apologies for the vague question (I'm new)â€¦ is there a good term for an API like `AsyncContext`â€¦ loosely immutable (`get` only), but overridable/censorable (with `run`) if you're calling new code?
content.formatted_body: apologies for the vague question (I'm new)â€¦ is there a good term for an API like AsyncContextâ€¦ loosely immutable (get only), but overridable/censorable (with run) if you're calling new code?

content.body: something like a "call stack-hugging environment variable"
Mark Miller (TC39 delegate) has been calling this a Fluid Variable
are we collecting use cases somewhere? maybe the proposal repo?
https://github.com/legendecas/proposal-async-context/issues/5
I tried looking for references for this, and it's all esoteric computer science papers and MIT's Scheme
I vaguely remember there used to be a `set` method along with `get`, but that's been removedâ€¦ is `set` gone for good? (My bias: I hope so, for predictability and efficiency)
content.formatted_body: I vaguely remember there used to be a set method along with get, but that's been removedâ€¦ is set gone for good? (My bias: I hope so, for predictability and efficiency)

content.body: (of course if you want mutability you can store an object of your own design in the `AsyncContext` and provide an API around that)
content.formatted_body: (of course if you want mutability you can store an object of your own design in the AsyncContext and provide an API around that)

content.body: I like that it's gone, because it prevents a memory leak
The Node folks mentioned that it's helpful for APM usage, though, so you don't need to redo the app
Even my company makes use of it, but I know how to update it once we get a real API
with no `set` method, I believe you're guaranteed the result of calling `ctx.get()` will always return the same value anywhere you call it in a given function body, which is a very useful invariant
content.formatted_body: with no set method, I believe you're guaranteed the result of calling ctx.get() will always return the same value anywhere you call it in a given function body, which is a very useful invariant

content.body: so you don't have to guess arbitrarily about how often you should poll the context for a new value within a given function
there's some work ongoing to eliminate the need for `set` in the APM cases
content.formatted_body: there's some work ongoing to eliminate the need for set in the APM cases

content.body:
> <@benjamn:matrix.org> I vaguely remember there used to be a `set` method along with `get`, but that's been removedâ€¦ is `set` gone for good? (My bias: I hope so, for predictability and efficiency)

I prefer omitting `set`, but rbuckton has argued in favor of including it
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @benjamn:matrix.org
I vaguely remember there used to be a set method along with get, but that's been removedâ€¦ is set gone for good? (My bias: I hope so, for predictability and efficiency)
I prefer omitting set, but rbuckton has argued in favor of including it

content.body: `set` usages can sometimes be replaced by using a single mutable object in the AsyncContext variable, and setting a property in that. Other times, that doesn't work, though.
content.formatted_body: set usages can sometimes be replaced by using a single mutable object in the AsyncContext variable, and setting a property in that. Other times, that doesn't work, though.

content.body: It'd be great to do a deeper analysis of use cases of `set`
content.formatted_body: It'd be great to do a deeper analysis of use cases of set

content.body: we *could* implement `set`, I'd prefer not to in general. just really dislike that model
content.formatted_body: we could implement set, I'd prefer not to in general. just really dislike that model

content.body: agreed
I'd at least like to be able to disable `set`, so `AsyncContext.prototype.set.call(<arbitrary context obj>, <new value>)` does not work
content.formatted_body: I'd at least like to be able to disable set, so AsyncContext.prototype.set.call(<arbitrary context obj>, <new value>) does not work

content.body: the thing I don't understand about set is how far it applies. Ron seemed to expect it to only take affect in the current function and "inwards", whereas another, simpler model would be for it to take effect across the whole innermost `run` where that particular variable was set. The latter can be implemented in terms of AsyncContext; the former requires some fancier core behavior
content.formatted_body: the thing I don't understand about set is how far it applies. Ron seemed to expect it to only take affect in the current function and "inwards", whereas another, simpler model would be for it to take effect across the whole innermost run where that particular variable was set. The latter can be implemented in terms of AsyncContext; the former requires some fancier core behavior

content.body: since Ron is also working on the resource management proposal, I wonder if he's interested in the region of time from when the resource is created to when it goes out of scope
well, yes, Ron has talked about how it's unfortunate that `run` forces you to put everything in a callback (which `using` avoids)
content.formatted_body: well, yes, Ron has talked about how it's unfortunate that run forces you to put everything in a callback (which using avoids)

content.body: but... I'm not personally convinced that this is so bad. I think people shouldn't be using `run` anywhere near the same order of magnitude of frequency as `using`.
content.formatted_body: but... I'm not personally convinced that this is so bad. I think people shouldn't be using run anywhere near the same order of magnitude of frequency as using.

content.body: if we had `set`, it'd be (potentially) a solution to this problem of forcing everything to be inside the callback (especially if it had the behavior Ron is arguing for, that it shouldn't leak out of the current function)
content.formatted_body: if we had set, it'd be (potentially) a solution to this problem of forcing everything to be inside the callback (especially if it had the behavior Ron is arguing for, that it shouldn't leak out of the current function)

content.body: (it may be that I misunderstood/misrepresented this suggestion; corrections welcome rbuckton )
content.formatted_body: (it may be that I misunderstood/misrepresented this suggestion; corrections welcome rbuckton )

content.body: I think of `run` as something you call "once per thread" (conceptually)
content.formatted_body: I think of run as something you call "once per thread" (conceptually)

content.body: (if you conceptualize async/await being a weird kind of threading with tons of forks)
if the only way to change the value of the `AsyncContext` is to run new code, then there's an especially convenient representation for the underlying collection of all contexts
content.formatted_body: if the only way to change the value of the AsyncContext is to run new code, then there's an especially convenient representation for the underlying collection of all contexts

content.body: roughly: an immutable map, where you can "add" elements in constant time by creating a new map in terms of old ones, and lookups are amortized O(1)
I know Justin Ridgewell was working on a similar/better(?) optimization in https://github.com/legendecas/proposal-async-context/pull/15
content.formatted_body: I know Justin Ridgewell was working on a similar/better(?) optimization in https://github.com/legendecas/proposal-async-context/pull/15

content.body: Yup
We can optimize it further if we know whether the current map was "frozen" by a `wrap`
content.formatted_body: We can optimize it further if we know whether the current map was "frozen" by a wrap

content.body: If it is, we need to reallocate to modify. If not, we can directly mutate
I believe there's even a way to use `WeakMap` here, so all values for a given `AsyncContext` go away if you discard that object
content.formatted_body: I believe there's even a way to use WeakMap here, so all values for a given AsyncContext go away if you discard that object

content.body: I know this may sound like premature optimization, but it's going to be hot code (in terms of CPU and memory) if we're not careful
From the JS side, unfortunately not, but as an actual implementation, the values should be weakly held by the keys
keys being `AsyncContext` instances?
content.formatted_body: keys being AsyncContext instances?

content.body: Yah
In pure spec terms, there's no reason we can clone a `WeakMap`
content.formatted_body: In pure spec terms, there's no reason we can clone a WeakMap

content.body: It's just not an API currently offered
true! funny how useless the data structure `ImmutableWeakMap` sounds, but something like that would be useful for this
content.formatted_body: true! funny how useless the data structure ImmutableWeakMap sounds, but something like that would be useful for this

content.body: it really doesn't need to be weak
but yes an immutable map structure would be useful here
private would be good enough, yes
yes, this is definitely private
but WeakMap doesn't make sense because there's no practical way that the AsyncContext variable can be garbage-collected while in the middle of a `run` with it.
content.formatted_body: but WeakMap doesn't make sense because there's no practical way that the AsyncContext variable can be garbage-collected while in the middle of a run with it.

content.body: Map is the better one
ImmutableMap could avoid the linear cloning cost, while preserving the fast lookup, but ultimately this is an optimization available to implementations
nothing visible in the API about whether it's implemented with Map or WeakMap or ImmutableMap
right
my point is, it's one of those optimizations that works best (for the implementations that choose to take advantage) if there are some restrictions in the API

Yeah I think we should just avoid using terms like "dynamic scoping" or "fluid variable" in the presentations and docs, since they just get us into debates about wording, and lose most of the audience

> <@littledan:matrix.org> (it may be that I misunderstood/misrepresented this suggestion; corrections welcome rbuckton )

I think that is a valid summary. It would be unfortunate to not have it, but not a deal breaker.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @littledan:matrix.org
(it may be that I misunderstood/misrepresented this suggestion; corrections welcome rbuckton )
I think that is a valid summary. It would be unfortunate to not have it, but not a deal breaker.

content.body:
> <@benjamn:matrix.org> my point is, it's one of those optimizations that works best (for the implementations that choose to take advantage) if there are some restrictions in the API

yes, `set` would definitely add complexity to the potential use of ImmutableMap (but not invalidate it I think)
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @benjamn:matrix.org
my point is, it's one of those optimizations that works best (for the implementations that choose to take advantage) if there are some restrictions in the API
yes, set would definitely add complexity to the potential use of ImmutableMap (but not invalidate it I think)

content.formatted_body: it would definitely be something to think through before concluding that we should have set

content.body: rbuckton: can you speak to what `set` can provide that mutable top-level context values (as an implementation detail) are not adequate for?
content.formatted_body: rbuckton: can you speak to what set can provide that mutable top-level context values (as an implementation detail) are not adequate for?

content.body: Is `AsyncContext` threaded through generators as well, or just async operations? If it isn't threaded through generators, then you could potentially write a generator function that `yield`s execution and upon returning control to the generator, evaluates *inside* of that context.
content.formatted_body: Is AsyncContext threaded through generators as well, or just async operations? If it isn't threaded through generators, then you could potentially write a generator function that yields execution and upon returning control to the generator, evaluates inside of that context.

content.body: Can you clarify what you mean by "mutable top-level context values"? I haven't caught up on the conversation
Itâ€™s not captured by gens, but itâ€™d be easy to implement in userland

(edited my text above a bit) if you `ctx.run([/*mutable array*/], () => { ... })` and code within that block has access to `ctx`, then they can do `ctx.get().push(...)` as if the context value was mutable
content.formatted_body: (edited my text above a bit) if you ctx.run([/*mutable array*/], () => { ... }) and code within that block has access to ctx, then they can do ctx.get().push(...) as if the context value was mutable

content.body: Once the gen.next call starts, inner code would not effect the outer context
`AsyncContext` is decidedly not just async operations (I sort of think the name undersells the sync side of the coin, where it also helps greatly)
content.formatted_body: AsyncContext is decidedly not just async operations (I sort of think the name undersells the sync side of the coin, where it also helps greatly)

content.body: Should it be captured by generators? It would be coherent to do so
there are two possible flows: the creation of the generator, when the whole thing could be bound to the current context, or each .next() call
oh, yeah, I guess I was imagining that, when the generator is created, it'd capture the current async context, and on each .next() call, it would restore that
I think it's important to decide what happens in generators, because async generators are also a thing
So `ctx.run(foo, () => gen.next())` wouldn't resume the generator inside of the context?
content.formatted_body: So ctx.run(foo, () => gen.next()) wouldn't resume the generator inside of the context?

content.body: The case Iâ€™m thinking of is koa, where an APM would be a middleware with a yield
right, since basically the thing that next() calls out to would be "wrapped" internally
We should move this into a GH issue, though

> <@benjamn:matrix.org> (edited my text above a bit) if you `ctx.run([/*mutable array*/], () => { ... })` and code within that block has access to `ctx`, then they can do `ctx.get().push(...)` as if the context value was mutable

so I'm wondering if that kind of object mutability is adequate for your use cases, or you really need the top-level context value to be changeable within the scope of a single function body
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @benjamn:matrix.org
(edited my text above a bit) if you ctx.run([/*mutable array*/], () => { ... }) and code within that block has access to ctx, then they can do ctx.get().push(...) as if the context value was mutable
so I'm wondering if that kind of object mutability is adequate for your use cases, or you really need the top-level context value to be changeable within the scope of a single function body

content.body: no rush to answer btw; I'm just trying to get my thoughts sorted out before the meeting next week

one use case I like to imagine is an async task runner system, where `run` gets called behind the scenes once per subtask, setting the current subtask object for that execution subtree, say

Do you mean the one that exists if you check the box in devtools?

content.body: right now I guess you'll see the immediately calling callstack when the wrapped function runs, not the one from wherever it was first wrapped (which could also be useful)
if the immediate caller is the event loop, maybe there's room to restore the previous async stack instead of showing nothing there
(not sure if this even remotely answers the question)

content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: it's also been shipping in Deno and Node for a while
content.body: it's also been shipping in Deno and Node for a while
always-on async stack traces have been a long-time feature request; I hadn't heard that that was granted, but if so, great
they ultimately run into the sort of buffer overrun issue that was raised in response to Yoav's talk at BlinkOn
but also, before then, there's a whole lot of bookkeeping
that's why, originally, it wasn't default-on
anyway if they made this cheaper: that's great!
https://docs.google.com/document/d/13Sy_kBIJGP0XT34V1CV3nkWya4TwYx9L3Yv45LdGB6Q/edit
Ah yes that's a different thing
that's why I started by asking "which one"

content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I didn't realize there were more than one
content.body: I didn't realize there were more than one
that is more limited to just async/await and sometimes doesn't work
I think that always-on mechanism will not interact with `wrap` or anything like that
content.formatted_body: I think that always-on mechanism will not interact with wrap or anything like that

content.body: Oh, I guess they got rid of the previous version and there has only been one for a while
the previous mechanism also worked for, e.g., setTimeout
Here's a description of the old version, clearly working without promises: https://developer.chrome.com/blog/async-call-stack/
and here's the release notes for the change: https://developer.chrome.com/blog/new-in-devtools-60/#async-stacks
I think, with the previous version, you'd expect `wrap` to continue the async stack trace. With the new version, you would not--it is specific to Promises.
content.formatted_body: I think, with the previous version, you'd expect wrap to continue the async stack trace. With the new version, you would not--it is specific to Promises.

content.body: I think they want you to manually tag your stacks now: https://developer.chrome.com/blog/devtools-modern-web-debugging/#:~:text=The%20Async%20Stack%20Tagging%20API%20introduces%20a%20new%20console%20method%20named%20console.createTask().%20The%20API%20signature%20is%20as%20follows%3A
